Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved

Comments_List: 30 hours.
10 hrs/week at the beginning, 5 hrs/week at the end
3 hours per week
1-2 hours
Depended a lot based on the week. When we had homework assignments I spent 3-6 hours working on them. When we did not have homework assignments I spent ~1-2 hours.
10hr+ for the first half of the semester, <3hrs for the second half
5 hours
2 hours

I liked that we had clear occupational exposure assessment demonstrations in the beginning of the course and read relevant literature. I think some of the lectures were too broad at times. I would like to see more case studies and in class study critiques.

Packed syllabus which can be a weakness at times because I felt like I couldnt keep up with reading. Hard graders but the subject is easy or was taught very surface level. It was sometimes hard to follow Professor.

I think this course was a bit too heavy on the front end of things. The first half of the semester was a lot of work, with assignments almost every week. These assignments could also be a lot of work like the problem sets and especially the biomarker assignment. The second half of the semester was a lot more relaxed which kind of makes up for the crunch of the first semester, but some more balance would be great. I also found the diet focused lecture to be the most engaging as it tied in new areas of research that many students in our department are interested in. Also, as someone who has spent over a year working in GIS, I would have preferred to have the option of attending the GIS workshop since I didn't learn much, but I do appreciate brining in GIS into the course for those that may not be familiar.

Online discussion boards felt like busy work. Would've appreciated more in class discussion of the readings instead. Discussion sections were used for guest lectures, which was fine, but we had two hours of lecture which easily could've allowed for more meaningful discussions on the readings.
Very well executed course. Enjoyed the topics and information was presented in a very helpful and clear way and I feel like I learned a lot.

This is a great class that gives an introduction to exposure science and exposure assessments/tools. The class materials are very informative and practical that everyone might use some of them in their career one day. The class assignments and exams truly reflect what we learn in class and encorage us to critically think about each exposure assessment. They expect you to appreciate and apply the tools, but by no means to nitpick on details.

The course felt somewhat repetitive of other EHS courses, such as environmental epidemiology and risk assessment. Although the topics were interesting, I did not think I learned a lot of new information from the class. I think the lab section could be expanded, since 50 minutes to do an actually meaningful lab is not sufficient. I most enjoyed the air sensor lab and thought this could have been made into a larger project in the course.
The course was well-structured and helpful, but workload was too much for the first half of the semester (and they only made up 40% of the final grade)
good coursehelp me learn a lot about exposure

This course is not well-suited for doctoral students, but it is useful for MPH-level students. A critical review of literature and methods is lacking, and it serves as an overview course. That being said, Nicole is an excellent instructor, provided timely feedback, and sought to ensure the students learned the material.
Very well structured but I felt that grading was extremely critical the first few weeks.
Great!!!
The homework assignments could have been broken into more smaller assignments. They could also have been more clear about what would matter in grading.

It is a good course. However, workload was not consistent. Most of the assignments have the same weight but some took couple of hours and some took couple of days. It was hard to keep up during midterm and finals week.

The best class I have ever taken. 

The instructor brought interesting questions and invited lecturers that can provide very comprehensive information on a certain topic.
good

Dr.D obviously knows her material. However, sometimes she speaks with some uncertainty or broken sentences that make it distracting. She is a great Professor and throughout the class she has shown speaking improvement however it's been consistently distracting. She is very kind and very smart. Just not the best at communication to her audience.

Dr. Deziel is a good instructor, she cares about her students and wants to teach us material that is engaging and relevant to our areas of study. She also really likes hearing about student experiences in the field and their opinions on different exposure assessment topics which I like!
I generally enjoyed her lectures more than the guest lecturers.
One of the best professors I have ever had.

Dr. Deziel is an excellent professor. She is so knowledgeable and always well-prepared for each class. She provides a positive learning environment and open to questions. She makes grading rubric for the assignments so its fair to everyone.
Dr. Deziel is very engaged with her students and seems to enjoy teaching.
She's excellent
Nicole is an excellent instructor, who answers questions thoroughly, and it always open to student input.
Dr. Deziel was amazing! She was very engaging and extremely organized.
Great!!!
Great. Helpful and easy to understand
She was interested in her topic and wanted to help students learn. I think she is still a new professor and getting used to teaching and that some of the work she assigned was unnecessary.

Great instructor. 
Always provide great examples. Make it easy to understand the concept.
very passionate professor

1. The work load of this course and instructions to the paper limited the students ability to think critically. Many times the instructor implied student should only do the way as instructed, while it may not be applied in the work field. 
2. The course did not cover many materials. The quality of slides, especially in the first few weeks, should be improved. Homework 1 and 2 needed some adjustments. For example, students should go into the real working field of welding and take samples and measurements. It seemed the instructor was taking it easy and judging the students homework hard, but the material itself was lack of content. The instructor should arrange some real world exposure sampling and should lead the student by doing it herself. 
3. The courses got better in the last few courses. In particular, the occupation matrix helped students understand the how work place exposure was measured. 
4. The work load of this course was over valued. It looked like a lot of instructions yet not  solid and applicable to real world exposure assessment.
Take the course if you are interested in the subject material, otherwise it will be dry.
This is a great class! I would definitely recommend everyone to take it!

This course provides some interesting information about exposure assessment, with some opportunity for hands on work. If you have taken a significant number of other environmental health courses, much of the information may be repetitive.

Very useful 
Yes
This course is a survey of exposure science. I would not recommend this course to doctoral-level researchers, for it is not in-depth enough. However, this class is useful for MPH-students.
This course teaches you the basics of environmental and occupational exposure assessment.
Excellent
I would only recommend it to someone interested in studying this exact topic. It was not as interesting for someone not interested in exposure assessment.
Definitely, recommend! Very helpful in the future research career.
goood
